title: Exploring chora-compose Integration for Inbox Automation
deliverables: Feasibility assessment of chora-compose for coordination request generation
Comparison of template-based vs demonstration-based generation approaches
Analysis of content block decomposition strategies
Recommendations for integration architecture and post-processing pipeline
Pilot plan for 4-week evaluation with measurable success criteria
acceptance_criteria: Feasibility assessment addresses ≥3 key integration challenges (schema mapping, conditional inclusion, post-processing)
Comparison evaluates ≥2 generation approaches with concrete examples
Content block analysis identifies ≥12 reusable patterns
Architecture recommendations include specific component diagrams and data flow
Pilot plan defines ≥80% quality threshold with 10-criterion rubric

context.background:
chora-base uses SAP-001 Inbox Coordination Protocol with a 3-tier intake system (coordination, task, proposal). Creating coordination requests manually currently takes 30-60 minutes of focused effort. chora-compose is a content generation framework with 17 production generators and MCP integration, designed for template-based and AI-augmented content creation.

This exploration assesses whether chora-compose can reduce coordination request generation time to 5-10 minutes while maintaining ≥80% quality. The investigation will examine architectural compatibility, content block decomposition, generation patterns, and post-processing requirements.

Success would enable significant productivity gains for chora-base contributors and provide a scalable foundation for task and proposal generation.
context.rationale: We considered three approaches: (1) manual templates with copy-paste, (2) chora-compose integration with content blocks, (3) custom Python generator. Manual templates lack validation and consistency. Custom generators require ongoing maintenance. chora-compose offers reusable content blocks, MCP integration, active maintenance, and a proven track record with 17 production generators. We chose an exploratory approach to validate feasibility and measure quality before committing to full implementation.
context.not_requesting: We are NOT asking chora-compose to modify its core architecture. We are NOT expecting you to implement our automation or maintain chora-base-specific tooling. This exploration does NOT commit us to adoption. We are NOT requesting urgent timeline or priority treatment.

Architecture and Compatibility: Can chora-compose support SAP-001's 18 required fields with proper nesting?
How do ContentElements map to our artifact types (coordination, task, proposal)?
What's the recommended approach for conditional field inclusion based on request type?
Generation Quality: What quality level can we expect from template-based generation?
Can AI-augmented generation achieve ≥80% coherence for background narratives?
How does demonstration-based generation handle acceptance criteria derivation?
Post-Processing Integration: Can we integrate chora-base-specific validation (inbox-status.py) in the pipeline?
How should we handle ID allocation from sequence files?
What's the best approach for event emission to events.jsonl?
Scalability and Reusability: What percentage of content blocks can be reused for task/proposal generation?
How maintainable are content configs as SAP-001 evolves?

collaboration_modes: Deep Collaboration: Joint exploration of integration architecture with 2-3 sync meetings, co-development of content configs, and iterative pilot evaluation. Estimated effort: 15-20 hours total.

Expert Consultation: Async guidance via GitHub discussions on key technical decisions (schema mapping, generation patterns, validation). Regular reviews of draft content configs. Estimated effort: 8-12 hours.
Technical Review: Review of our proposed integration design with specific feedback on architecture and content block structure. Estimated effort: 4-6 hours.
High-Level Guidance: Quick assessment of feasibility with high-level recommendations on approach and potential challenges. Estimated effort: 1-2 hours.
